On 11/27/06, Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@...> wrote:
>
> In my book=
, a beautiful unit test is one that tests as much as possible,
> as simply =
as possible.  I don't usually associate "clever" with "keep is
> simple stu=
pid" but maybe that's just me.  I think a beautiful JUnit test
> would be o=
ne that uses both inheritance and the "parameterized test
> case" pattern t=
o be as short and sweet (and therefore maintainable) as
> possible.


Perso=
nally (and as you say, code beauty is in the beholder's eye), I
wouldn't co=
unt test code that uses the parameterized test case pattern as
"beautiful",=
 because this design pattern only exists to address a limitation
in JUnit 3=
, and for that reason, it obfuscates the code more than it
prettifies it (o=
ne of the reasons why "modern" test frameworks let you pass
parameters dire=
ctly to your test methods).

I would give a similar "thumbs down" to the "e=
xception design pattern":  it
adds a lot of noise to the test code, thereby=
 hiding its true intent (and
similarly, it's been addressed in modern test =
frameworks by letting users
specify that an exception is expected from the =
test method directly in the
annotation).

-- 
C=E9dric
http://testng.org
